The angle of the polar grid is kept constant with the following theory.

<img src="http://bobbinwork.googlecode.com/svn/wiki/images/GridMath/angle.gif" alt="grid-math.gif" title="grid-math.gif">

When _a_ is small and _r_ large, the small edge of the pie could be considered straight.

With _b = 45_ degrees, _r,,1,,_ equals the small pie edge.

The approximation above in math: 
<img src="http://bobbinwork.googlecode.com/svn/wiki/images/GridMath/form1.gif" title="r_1 = \frac{ 2*\pi*r }{ nr \ of \ segments }" alt="r_1 = \frac{ 2*\pi*r }{ nr \ of \ segments }" align="absmiddle">

For the circle we get:
<img src="http://bobbinwork.googlecode.com/svn/wiki/images/GridMath/form2.gif" title="r_2 = \frac{ 2*\pi*(r + r_1) }{ nr \ of \ segments }" alt="r_2 = \frac{ 2*\pi*(r + r_1) }{ nr \ of \ segments }" align="absmiddle">

From the mathematical rule:
<img src="http://bobbinwork.googlecode.com/svn/wiki/images/GridMath/form3.gif" title="tan(b) = \frac{ r_1 }{ curve \ length }" alt="tan(b) = \frac{ r_1 }{ curve \ length }" align="absmiddle">

we can deduce:
<img src="http://bobbinwork.googlecode.com/svn/wiki/images/GridMath/form4.gif" title="r_1 = \frac{ 2 * \pi * r * tan(b) }{ nr \ of \ segments }" alt="r_1 = \frac{ 2 * \pi * r * tan(b) }{ nr \ of \ segments }" align="absmiddle">
